title: Milt Jordan
text:
Milton Mignot Jordan (May 24, 1927 – May 13, 1993) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player, a , right-handed <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who appeared in eight <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League</a> <a href="games%20played">games</a> for the <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a>. He was born in <a href="Clearfield%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Mineral Springs, Clearfield County, Pennsylvania</a>, and served in the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Forces">United States Army Air Forces</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Jordan's nine-season (1948–1956) career was spent entirely in the Tiger organization. His Major League trial came at the outset of the <a href="1953%20Detroit%20Tigers%20season">1953 campaign</a>. After two scoreless appearances as a <a href="relief%20pitcher">relief pitcher</a>, Jordan was given his only MLB <a href="starting%20pitcher">starting</a> assignment by <a href="manager%20%28baseball%29">manager</a> <a href="Fred%20Hutchinson">Fred Hutchinson</a> on April 22 against the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> at <a href="Briggs%20Stadium">Briggs Stadium</a>. In the second inning he surrendered three <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a> but went on to last seven full innings, giving up six runs, all <a href="earned%20run">earned</a> and 12 <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a>, including <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a> by Chicago's <a href="Sam%20Mele">Sam Mele</a>, <a href="Sherm%20Lollar">Sherm Lollar</a> and <a href="Vern%20Stephens">Vern Stephens</a>. He departed with the Tigers trailing 6–1, and absorbed the loss in an eventual 9–7 defeat. It was his only Major League <a href="decision%20%28baseball%29">decision</a>. In 17 innings, he allowed 26 hits, 11 earned runs and five <a href="bases%20on%20balls">bases on balls</a>, with four <a href="strikeouts">strikeouts</a>.
In 1953, Jordan won 12, lost only once, and compiled a 3.11 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> for the Triple-A <a href="Buffalo%20Bisons">Buffalo Bisons</a> of the <a href="International%20League">International League</a>, mostly working as a relief pitcher.
